column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=244x235 at 0x313828770>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with black eyes to offspring with red eyes? Choose the most likely ratio.	['1:3'

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with black eyes or red eyes
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the eye color trait. The question tells you that the E allele
column3: which is for red eyes
column4: is dominant over the e allele
column5: which is for black eyes.

column1: Black eyes is the recessive allele's version of the eye color trait. A koi fish with the recessive version of the eye color trait must have only recessive alleles for the eye color gene. So
column2: offspring with black eyes must have the genotype ee.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype ee.
Red eyes is the dominant allele's version of the eye color trait. A koi fish with the dominant version of the eye color trait must have at least one dominant allele for the eye color gene. So
column2: offspring with red eyes must have the genotype EE or Ee.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype EE or Ee.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with black eyes to offspring with red eyes is 4:0. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will always produce offspring with black eyes. This cross is expected to never produce offspring with red eyes."	"ANSWER: (2) 4:0

column1: SOLUTION: The question involves a Punnett square where all 4 boxes represent the genotype 'ee'
column2: indicating black eyes - the recessive trait. There are no boxes with the genotype 'EE' or 'Ee'
column3: which would indicate red eyes - the dominant trait. Therefore
column4: the expected ratio of offspring with black eyes to offspring with red eyes is 4:0
column5: meaning all offspring are expected to have black eyes based on the provided genetic cross."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Did you really vote for Richard as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?"	['circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Richard can't be trusted with money, because his uncle embezzled money. However, even though his uncle couldn't be trusted with money, that doesn't necessarily mean that Richard can't be trusted with it. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text is using guilt by association
column2: suggesting that because Richard's uncle was guilty of embezzlement
column3: Richard might also be untrustworthy
column4: even though there is no direct evidence of any wrongdoing on Richard's part. This is a fallacy because one's character or actions cannot be determined based on their association with someone else. Therefore
column5: the correct answer is '1 - guilt by association'."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.

column2: the batter changes into a different substance. Similarly
column3: the formation of rust is a reaction between iron and oxygen
column4: resulting in a different substance again. Hence
column5: the common factor between these two processes is that they are both chemical changes."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Don't ever get a ride from Mariana. Her brother has been driving for only six months

column3: 'circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself']	0		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Mariana must be a reckless driver, because her brother is a reckless driver. However, even though Mariana's brother is reckless, that doesn't necessarily mean that Mariana is, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text commits the fallacy of ""guilt by association"" by assuming that Mariana must be a reckless driver because her brother is one. The argument is trying to discredit Mariana's driving skills based on her brother's poor record
column2: which is not a valid logical connection. The text does not provide any evidence that Mariana herself is a bad driver
column3: so it's incorrect to assume her guilt based on her brother's actions."

column1: Lines of latitude show how far north or south a place is. We use units called degrees to describe how far a place is from the equator. The equator is the line located at 0Â° latitude. We start counting degrees from there.
Lines north of the equator are labeled N for north. Lines south of the equator are labeled S for south. Lines of latitude are also called parallels because each line is parallel to the equator.

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants

column1: When a word changes in meaning
column2: its correct usage is often debated. Although a newer sense of the word may be more commonly used
column3: many people consider a word's traditional definition to be the correct usage. Being able to distinguish the different uses of a word can help you use it appropriately for different audiences.

column1: Britney perused her notes
column2: carefully preparing for her exam.

column1: The traditional usage above is considered more standard.
David perused the magazine
column2: absentmindedly flipping through the pages.

SOLUTION: The first text uses 'disinterested' in its traditional sense

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
I don't trust Professor Chang's findings. Another researcher at her university was caught falsifying data. So
column2: it's likely Professor Chang has
column3: too."	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column4: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something'
column5: 'bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct']"	1		closed choice	grade10	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Professor Chang's research is untrustworthy because someone else at her university was caught falsifying data. However, this isn't necessarily true. The practices of one researcher at a university do not necessarily reflect the practices of another researcher at the same university. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text implies that because another researcher at Professor Chang's university was caught falsifying data
column2: Professor Chang must be doing the same. This is an example of the guilt by association fallacy. The text is trying to discredit Professor Chang's findings based on her association with a university where dishonest research has been conducted
column3: even though there is no direct evidence that Professor Chang herself has been dishonest."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Melting glass is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. The glass changes from solid to liquid. But a different type of matter is not formed.

column1: Cooking an egg is a chemical change. The heat causes the matter in the egg to change. Cooked egg and raw egg are different types of matter.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Melting glass is a physical change. But cooking an egg is not.
Both are chemical changes.
Cooking an egg is a chemical change. But melting glass is not.
Both are caused by heating.
Both changes are caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Both melting glass and cooking an egg involve the application of heat. Melting glass is a physical change
column2: as it changes from solid to liquid state but still remains glass. Cooking an egg
column3: on the other hand
column4: is a chemical change
column5: as the heat transforms the raw egg into a cooked one
column6: changing its molecular structure. Therefore
column7: the common factor is that both processes are caused by heating."

An animal's circulatory system is made up of organs that work together to move blood through its body. The heart pumps blood through blood vessels throughout the body. As blood moves through blood vessels

column4: and water to cells. Blood also absorbs waste

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
A rainbow appeared in the sky the day before basketball tryouts
column2: and I made the team! If there's a rainbow when I try out in the spring
column3: I'm sure I'll make the team again."	"[""ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent""
column4: 'false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together
column5: one caused the other']"	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that the rainbow is responsible for the speaker making the basketball team. However, even though the speaker made the team after the rainbow appeared, that doesn't necessarily mean that the rainbow was responsible. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as false causation.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The speaker in the text is associating the appearance of the rainbow with their success in making the basketball team
column2: suggesting that the two events are causally linked. However
column3: there is no logical or factual basis for this connection. This is an example of the false causation fallacy
column4: where one falsely assigns cause and effect to two events that occur together."

column1: To fix a run-on sentence
column2: separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence
column3: and capitalize the second sentence.

It started raining. We ran inside.
You can also fix a run-on sentence by rewriting it as a compound sentence. A compound sentence is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: I knocked on the door
column2: and it opened.

column1: It started raining

column1: SOLUTION: The sentence ""Jayla is from Springdale now she lives in Dover"" is a run-on sentence. A run-on sentence is when two or more independent clauses (complete sentences) are joined without an appropriate punctuation or conjunction. In this case
column2: ""Jayla is from Springdale"" and ""now she lives in Dover"" are two independent clauses that are improperly connected without a comma or conjunction."

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence

The text argues that President Ballard is an effective communicator because he communicates well. However

column3: saying President Ballard is an effective communicator because he has a natural talent for speaking with people is just repeating the same point and not providing any concrete evidence to support the claim."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a physical change

column7: the answer is 'Both are only physical changes'."

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

A food web has arrows that point from one organism to another. Each arrow shows the direction that matter moves when one organism eats another organism. An arrow starts from the organism that is eaten. The arrow points to the organism that is doing the eating.
An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.

An organism in a food web can also have more than one arrow pointing to it. This shows that the organism eats more than one other organism in the food web."	"Tertiary consumers eat secondary consumers. So
column2: in a food web

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with a white body or a brown body

column2: offspring with a brown body must have the genotype BB or Bb.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype BB or Bb.
So

column4: this cross will never produce offspring with a white body. Instead

column4: and since there are no boxes in the Punnett square with this genotype
column5: no offspring with a white body are expected. Hence

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.

An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.

A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.

Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.

column6: attributing this human behavior to a nonhuman object is a clear case of personification."

column1: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?	"[""Leah roomed with Olivia last year
column2: but Olivia's messiness became a point of contention.""
column3: 'Leah roomed with Olivia last year
column4: but her messiness became a point of contention.']"	1		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Pronouns and antecedents	Identify vague pronoun references	"When writing
column5: make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.

column1: When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: she breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim
column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: 2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they
column2: them
column3: their
column4: theirs
column5: it
column6: or its is used without its antecedent.

column1: They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent
column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes."	"The second answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun her could refer to Leah's or Olivia's.
The first answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. Her has been replaced with Olivia's.
Leah roomed with Olivia last year
column2: but Olivia's messiness became a point of contention."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The sentence ""Leah roomed with Olivia last year
column2: but her messiness became a point of contention"" has a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun 'her' could refer to either Leah or Olivia
column3: thus creating confusion about whose messiness is being referred to. On the other hand
column4: in the first sentence
column5: the use of ""Olivia's"" clarifies that the messiness is Olivia's
column6: eliminating any ambiguity."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
crushing a mineral into powder
knitting yarn into a scarf"	['Both are chemical changes.'
column2: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column3: 'Both are caused by cooling.'
column4: 'Both are caused by heating.']	1		closed choice	grade7	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Crushing a mineral into powder is a physical change. The mineral breaks into tiny pieces. But it is still made of the same type of matter.
Knitting yarn into a scarf is a physical change. The yarn gets a different shape
column2: but it is still made of the same type of matter.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. They are not chemical changes.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Both actions
column2: crushing a mineral into powder and knitting yarn into a scarf
column3: cause a change in form but not in the substance itself. This indicates that they are physical changes
column4: not chemical ones
column5: because the substance's identity remains the same. Both changes are not caused by heating or cooling
column6: ruling out the other options. Therefore

column1: Which is a compound sentence?	"[""Mr. Buchanan's afternoon lecture was about art and culture in Germany before World War II.""

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought. It can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause is not a complete thought. It cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.

column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column3: or

column1: We saw a flash of lightning

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause usually begins with a subordinating conjunction such as after

column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column11: or while.

column1: If she ever gets the chance

column8: so) or a semicolon. In this case
column9: the two independent clauses ""Preston couldn't find the definition for flax in the book's glossary"" and ""he looked it up online"" are connected by the coordinating conjunction 'so'."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column4: 'Both are caused by heating.']	1		closed choice	grade4	natural science	chemistry	Physical and chemical change	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Crushing a mineral into powder is a physical change. The mineral breaks into tiny pieces. But it is still made of the same type of matter.
Pouring milk on oatmeal is a physical change. The oatmeal and milk form a creamy mixture. But making this mixture does not form a different type of matter.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. They are not chemical changes.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.

SOLUTION: Crushing a mineral into a powder and pouring milk on oatmeal are both physical changes. This is because the substances involved retain their original properties and do not form new substances. Neither change is caused by heating or cooling
column2: and neither change is a chemical change. Therefore
column3: the correct answer is ""Both are only physical changes""."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Tyler must be fiscally irresponsible, because he works for a company that went bankrupt. However, even though his company is perceived as fiscally irresponsible, that doesn't necessarily mean that Tyler is, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text implies that because Tyler works for a company that has filed for bankruptcy
column2: he can't be trusted with money. This is an example of the guilt by association fallacy because it unfairly associates Tyler's trustworthiness with the financial status of his employer. The financial situation of the company does not necessarily reflect on Tyler's personal financial responsibility or trustworthiness."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Did you really vote for Edgar as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?"	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']"	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Edgar can't be trusted with money, because his uncle embezzled money. However, even though his uncle couldn't be trusted with money, that doesn't necessarily mean that Edgar can't be trusted with it. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text implies that Edgar should not be trusted as a treasurer because his uncle was involved in a financial crime. It is trying to discredit Edgar based on his association with his uncle
column2: rather than his own actions or capabilities. Therefore
column3: this is an example of the 'guilt by association' fallacy
column4: making option 1 the correct answer."

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses personification

column5: making the answer 'personification'. Simile is not used in this text as there is no comparison being made."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Leah should either stop reading those sappy paranormal romance novels or finally admit that she doesn't believe in empowering women."	['bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct'
column2: 'slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences'
column3: 'false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist']	2		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Leah either must give up reading a certain type of book or admit she doesn't believe in female empowerment. However, someone can both enjoy reading paranormal romance books and also believe in empowering women. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a false dichotomy.	ANSWER: 2
SOLUTION: The given statement presents only two options for Leah
column2: without considering that she could possibly enjoy paranormal romance novels and also believe in women's empowerment. Therefore
column3: this argument is a false dichotomy
column4: which assumes only two alternatives exist when in fact more options are possible. Hence
column5: the logical fallacy used in the text is a false dichotomy."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

How can I be expected to do my homework when billions of people around the world are throwing their plastic water bottles away without recycling them?"	['circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column2: 'red herring: the use of a completely unrelated topic or idea']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that people not recycling somehow prevents the speaker from doing homework. However, these two ideas aren't related. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a red herring.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The argument presented diverges from the main topic of homework to an unrelated issue of recycling. The speaker uses the unrelated issue of people not recycling their plastic bottles as a distraction from the main issue which is doing homework. This is a classic example of the logical fallacy known as a red herring."

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.

An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

A euphemism is a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The head of Human Resources would never refer to firing people
column2: only to laying them off.

column1: Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.

An oxymoron is a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.

A paradox is a statement that might at first appear to be contradictory
column2: but that may in fact contain some truth.

column1: Always expect the unexpected.
Understatement involves deliberately representing something as less serious or important than it really is.
As you know
column2: it can get a little cold in the Antarctic."	"The text uses chiasmus

column1: The second time they appear

column3: which is a figure of speech that directly addresses an absent person or a personified abstraction."

Think about two objects moving for the same amount of time. The object that is moving faster will go a farther distance in that time. It is moving at a higher speed."	"Look at the distance each mountain biker moved and the time it took to move that distance.
One mountain biker moved 255 kilometers in 10 hours.
The other mountain biker moved 190 kilometers in 10 hours.
Notice that each mountain biker spent the same amount of time moving. The mountain biker who moved 255 kilometers moved a farther distance in that time. So
column2: that mountain biker must have moved at a higher speed."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Speed is calculated by dividing the distance traveled by the time taken. Both mountain bikers spent the same amount of time biking - 10 hours. However
column2: the biker who covered 255 kilometers in that time must have been moving at a higher speed than the biker who covered only 190 kilometers in the same time period. Hence
column3: the mountain biker who moved 255 kilometers in 10 hours was moving at a higher speed."

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring

column1: For example

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype HH or Hh.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype hh.

column1: Which is a complex sentence?	['Freedom of speech and trial by jury are two important rights in the United States Constitution.'
column2: 'Mackenzie and her mom sat on the back porch and watched as the sun sank into the horizon.']	1		closed choice	grade5	language science	grammar	Sentences
column3: fragments
column4: and run-ons	Is the sentence simple
column5: compound
column6: or complex?	"A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a predicate.

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought. It can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause is not a complete thought. It cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw a flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard the rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause usually begins with a subordinating conjunction such as after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column11: or while.

column1: If she ever gets the chance
column2: Terri would love to visit the Egyptian pyramids."	"The first sentence is the complex sentence. It is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause begins with the subordinating conjunction as.

column1: Mackenzie and her mom sat on the back porch and watched as the sun sank into the horizon."	"ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The sentence ""Mackenzie and her mom sat on the back porch and watched as the sun sank into the horizon."" is a complex sentence. A complex sentence consists of an independent clause and at least one dependent clause. In this case
column2: ""Mackenzie and her mom sat on the back porch"" is an independent clause that can stand alone. ""As the sun sank into the horizon"" is a dependent clause which cannot stand alone as a sentence. It is connected to the independent clause with the subordinating conjunction ""as""."

column1: Which is a run-on sentence?	['In the story

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that Mr. Leonard can quit smoking because he is able to stop. However
column2: the ""evidence"" is just a restatement of the claim itself. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as circular reasoning."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So

column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait

column1: Some traits

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Did you really vote for Porter as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?"	['guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something'

When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Porter can't be trusted with money, because his uncle embezzled money. However, even though his uncle couldn't be trusted with money, that doesn't necessarily mean that Porter can't be trusted with it. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text is using the guilt by association logical fallacy. Here
column2: the speaker is trying to discredit Porter's credibility as a class treasurer based on the actions of his uncle. This fallacy suggests that because Porter's uncle was involved in financial crime
column3: Porter must be untrustworthy as well
column4: which is not necessarily true. It's a fallacy because the character or actions of one person don't necessarily reflect on their relatives."

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"You need to determine Jack's phenotype for the cheek color trait. First

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Burning a candle is a chemical change. Both the wick and the melted wax burn. They react with oxygen in the air and turn into soot
column2: carbon dioxide
column3: and water.

column1: Melting glass is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. The glass changes from solid to liquid. But a different type of matter is not formed.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Melting glass is a physical change. But burning a candle is not.
Both are chemical changes.
Burning a candle is a chemical change. But melting glass is not.
Both are caused by heating.
Both changes are caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: (2)
SOLUTION: Both burning a candle and melting glass are changes that occur due to the application of heat. In the case of the candle

column3: heat is required to change its state from solid to liquid. Therefore
column4: the common factor between these two changes is that they are both caused by heating."

column3: Blake uses anaphora to underscore the pervasiveness and universality of the ""mind-forg'd manacles"" he hears."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
cooking an egg

column2: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column3: 'Both are caused by heating.'
column4: 'Both are caused by cooling.']	0		closed choice	grade7	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Cooking an egg is a chemical change. The heat causes the matter in the egg to change. Cooked egg and raw egg are different types of matter.

Salt and vinegar removing tarnish from a penny is a chemical change. The salt and vinegar change the tarnish into a different type of matter that can be easily wiped away. This makes the penny look shiny again.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Cooking is caused by heating. But salt and vinegar removing tarnish from a penny is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: Cooking an egg and removing tarnish from a penny with salt and vinegar are both examples of chemical changes. In both cases
column2: the original matter is altered to become a different type of matter: a raw egg becomes a cooked egg
column3: and tarnish becomes easily removable residue. Neither are physical changes or changes caused by heating or cooling alone. Therefore
column4: the correct answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column5: 'hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations']	2		closed choice	grade11	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that a week without rain is evidence that Seattle isn't a rainy city. However, the experience of one week doesn't necessarily reflect longer trends in a place's climate. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a hasty generalization.	ANSWER: 2
SOLUTION: The statement makes a broad claim about Seattle's climate based on just one week of observation
column2: which is insufficient data to make such generalization. This is a perfect example of a hasty generalization
column3: a logical fallacy where a person draws a conclusion about a population based on a small sample that is not representative. Hence
column4: the logical fallacy used in the text is a hasty generalization."

Fallacy | Description

A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:

column1: A certain fruit fly from this group has the heterozygous genotype Ee for the eye color gene."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"You need to determine the fruit fly's phenotype for the eye color trait. First

column1: The allele for brown eyes (e) is recessive to the allele for red eyes (E). This means E is a dominant allele
column2: and e is a recessive allele.

column1: The fruit fly's genotype of Ee has one dominant allele and one recessive allele. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So
column2: the fruit fly's phenotype for the eye color trait must be red eyes."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The fruit fly's genotype is Ee
column2: where E is the dominant gene for red eye color and e is the recessive gene for brown eye color. As per the law of dominance
column3: in a heterozygous condition
column4: the dominant gene is expressed. Hence
column5: the fruit fly's phenotype would be red eyes. So
column6: the answer is 0 for red eyes."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
The number of off-leash dogs I've seen in Booneville is completely unacceptable. Let's make our streets safe again by addressing this dog problem
column2: before our city becomes a haven for criminals."	['false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together
column3: one caused the other'
column4: 'red herring: the use of a completely unrelated topic or idea']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that off-leash dogs would somehow cause an increase in crime in Booneville. However, these two ideas aren't related. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a red herring.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text falsely links the presence of off-leash dogs to an increase in criminal activity
column2: which is a distraction from the primary issue at hand. This is a classic example of a red herring fallacy
column3: where a secondary issue is introduced in order to divert attention from the main argument. The text does not provide any evidence or logical reasoning to substantiate the claim that off-leash dogs will lead to a rise in crime
column4: hence
column5: answer 1 is the correct one."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column3: 'Both are caused by heating.'
column4: 'Both are only physical changes.']	2		closed choice	grade8	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Water boiling on the stove is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. The liquid changes into a gas
column3: but a different type of matter is not formed.

column1: Baking an apple pie is a chemical change. The type of matter in the pie changes when it is baked. The crust turns brown
column2: and the apples become soft.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Water boiling is a physical change. But baking a pie is not.
Both are chemical changes.
Baking a pie is a chemical change. But water boiling is not.
Both are caused by heating.
Both changes are caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: (2)
SOLUTION: Both water boiling on a stove and baking an apple pie are processes that require heating. Boiling is a physical change that occurs when water is heated
column2: and baking an apple pie involves a chemical change that is also facilitated by heat. Neither of the processes is caused by cooling
column3: and the changes involved are not exclusively physical or chemical. Therefore
column4: the commonality between these two changes is that they are both caused by heating."

column1: A certain tomato plant from this group has the homozygous genotype ff for the fruit texture gene."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw the flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column11: and while. Relative pronouns include that

column1: During his trip to Italy
column2: Tony visited the Trevi Fountain

column1: A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.

column2: she stopped at the bank
column3: and then she went to the gym.

column1: Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.

Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins."	"The sentence is complex. It is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause begins with the subordinating conjunction as.
As Brian sat down on the rickety old chair
column2: it abruptly collapsed beneath him."	"ANSWER: 2

column1: SOLUTION: The given sentence is a complex sentence. A complex sentence has one independent clause and one or more dependent clauses. In this case

column3: ""As Brian sat down on the rickety old chair
column4: cannot stand alone because it does not express a complete thought. The dependent clause begins with the subordinating conjunction 'as'
column5: which connects it to the independent clause."

column1: Assonance is the repetition of a vowel sound in a series of nearby words.
