column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance

column6: or forms

column1: For example

column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers

column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So

column1: Select the part whose main job is to store nutrients
column2: water
column3: and waste in a plant cell.	['Golgi'
column4: 'chromosomes'
column5: 'nucleus'
column6: 'vacuole']	3		closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Cells	Identify functions of plant cell parts	"Plant cells are made up of many different parts. Each cell part has a function that helps the cell survive and grow.

column1: Some cell parts are called organelles. Organelles are cell structures that are surrounded by their own membranes. Here are some of the organelles in plant cells:

Chloroplasts and mitochondria work together to help the cell get the energy it needs. The chloroplasts use photosynthesis to make sugar. The mitochondria break down this sugar and release energy that the cell can use for all of its activities.

The nucleus directs cell activities by sending instructions to different parts of the cell. The nucleus contains structures called chromosomes. The chromosomes are made mostly of hereditary material called DNA. DNA contains information that the cell uses for growth and activities. These instructions tell ribosomes how to build molecules called proteins
column2: which make up cell structures and help chemical reactions happen in the cell.

column1: The endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle that helps ribosomes build proteins. The nucleus sends instructions for making proteins to ribosomes. Ribosomes can attach to the endoplamic reticulum. The endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes use these instructions to make proteins that the cell needs to survive and grow.
After proteins are made in the endoplasmic reticulum
column2: they can be transferred to the Golgi. The Golgi is an organelle made up of flat
column3: stacked membranes. The Golgi sorts and packages proteins and other substances. Then
column4: the Golgi sends these substances to different parts of the cell. Some of these substances are sent to the cell membrane and released from the cell.

column1: In plant cells
column2: the vacuole stores waste
column3: water
column4: and nutrients such as sugar. Most plant cells have one vacuole.

column1: Other cell parts are not surrounded by their own membranes. These cell parts are not organelles.
The cell wall is the cell's tough outer covering. It gives the cell strength and stiffness and helps the cell keep its shape.
On the inside of the cell wall is a thin layer called the cell membrane. This layer is a membrane
column2: but it does not have a membrane surrounding it
column3: so it is not an organelle. The cell membrane controls which substances enter and leave the cell.

column1: The cytoplasm is a thick liquid that fills the space inside the cell. The cytoplasm also helps the cell keep its shape and supports the other cell parts."	The vacuole stores water
column2: waste
column3: and nutrients such as sugar. Plant cells usually have one vacuole.	"ANSWER: 3

column1: SOLUTION: The vacuole is an organelle in a plant cell whose main job is to store nutrients
column2: water
column3: and waste materials. It acts as a storage unit
column4: playing a crucial role in maintaining the cell's internal environment. The other options like Golgi
column5: chromosomes and nucleus perform different roles. The Golgi apparatus is involved in protein sorting
column6: chromosomes carry genetic information
column7: and the nucleus controls the cell's activities."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=236x235 at 0x31382BF80>	What is the expected ratio of offspring that have thorns to offspring that do not have thorns? Choose the most likely ratio.	['2:2'
column5: '3:1']	2	"In a group of rose plants
column6: some individuals have thorns and others do not. In this group

column1: This Punnett square shows a cross between two rose plants."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types	"Offspring phenotypes: dominant or recessive?

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring that do or do not have thorns
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the thorns trait. The question tells you that the R allele
column3: which is for having thorns
column4: is dominant over the r allele
column5: which is for not having thorns.

column1: Having thorns is the dominant allele's version of the thorns trait. A rose plant with the dominant version of the thorns trait must have at least one dominant allele for the thorns gene. So
column2: offspring that have thorns must have the genotype RR or Rr.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype RR or Rr.
Not having thorns is the recessive allele's version of the thorns trait. A rose plant with the recessive version of the thorns trait must have only recessive alleles for the thorns gene. So
column2: offspring that do not have thorns must have the genotype rr.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype rr.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring that have thorns to offspring that do not have thorns is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring that have thorns. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring that do not have thorns."	"ANSWER: (2) 0:4

column1: SOLUTION: The task involves reading the given Punnett square and determining the ratio of offspring with the dominant trait (having thorns) to offspring with the recessive trait (not having thorns). As per the information
column2: no boxes in the Punnett square have the dominant genotype (RR or Rr)
column3: which signifies offspring with thorns. However
column4: all four boxes have the recessive genotype (rr)
column5: which signifies offspring without thorns. Hence
column6: the expected ratio is 0:4."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
When Carson arrived at Heathrow Airport
column2: a British man helped him retrieve his luggage from baggage claim. British people are all so nice!"	['guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something'
column3: 'hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations'
column4: 'appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good']	1		closed choice	grade11	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that a single polite British person indicates that all British people are nice. However, this isn't necessarily true. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a hasty generalization.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text is making a broad assumption about the character of all British people based on a single interaction with one British man. This is a perfect example of a hasty generalization
column2: where conclusions are drawn from insufficient evidence. It's not logical to categorize every British person as ""nice"" based on one person's actions. The text is therefore committing fallacy number 1
column3: a hasty generalization."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column3: 'red herring: the use of a completely unrelated topic or idea']"	0		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that you don't want your grandmother to have a dog, because you want her to be lonely. However, the fact that you don't want her to have a dog doesn't necessarily suggest that you want her to be lonely. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text makes an assumption about the reason behind not wanting to get a dog for the grandmother
column2: suggesting that it's because you want her to be sad and lonely. This is a misrepresentation of your position
column3: making it easier to argue against. This is an example of a straw man fallacy
column4: hence answer 0 is correct."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Ms. Stafford has suggested that our schools let students take statistics instead of algebra to graduate. Frankly
column2: it is puzzling to me that she thinks algebra is a useless subject."	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column3: 'appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good'
column4: 'bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct']"	0		closed choice	grade12	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Ms. Stafford thinks algebra is useless because she would let students take statistics instead. However, Ms. Stafford only claimed that students should be allowed to take statistics instead of algebra. She did not suggest that algebra is a useless subject. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text misrepresents Ms. Stafford's suggestion of allowing students to take statistics instead of algebra as her declaring algebra a useless subject. This is an example of a ""straw man"" fallacy
column2: where a person's argument is distorted or exaggerated to make it easier to attack or refute. Therefore
column3: the correct answer is 0
column4: which corresponds to the definition of a straw man fallacy."

column1: Select the elementary substance.	['cyclopropane (C3H6)'
column2: 'argon (Ar)'
column3: 'phosphine (PH3)']	1		closed choice	grade5	natural science	chemistry	Atoms and molecules	Identify elementary substances and compounds using chemical formulas	"Every substance around you is made of one or more chemical elements
column4: or types of atoms. Substances that are made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds.

column1: Every chemical element is represented by its own symbol. For some elements
column2: the symbol is one capital letter. For other elements
column3: the symbol is one capital letter and one lowercase letter. For example
column4: the symbol for the element fluorine is F
column5: and the symbol for the element beryllium is Be.

column1: The symbol for each element in a substance is shown in the substance's chemical formula.
An elementary substance is represented by a chemical formula that contains only one symbol.

The symbol may be followed by a subscript. A subscript is text that is smaller and placed lower than the normal line of text. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript tells you the number of atoms in each molecule.
For example
column2: the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen is O2. The formula has a subscript of 2. This subscript tells you that there are two atoms in the molecule represented by this chemical formula.

column1: The chemical element represented by the symbol O is also called oxygen. So
column2: the formula O2 tells you that each molecule of O2 contains two oxygen atoms.

column1: A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple symbols.
For example
column2: in the compound beryllium fluoride
column3: there is one beryllium atom for every two fluorine atoms. This combination is shown in the compound's chemical formula
column4: BeF2. In the formula
column5: the symbol Be represents one beryllium atom. The symbol F followed by the subscript 2 represents two fluorine atoms."	Look at the chemical formula for each substance
column6: and count the number of symbols in the formula. Then
column7: decide if the substance is an elementary substance. The chemical formula for cyclopropane contains two symbols: C for carbon and H for hydrogen. So
column8: cyclopropane is made of two chemical elements bonded together. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds. So
column10: not an elementary substance. The chemical formula for phosphine contains two symbols: P for phosphorus and H for hydrogen. So
column11: phosphine is made of two chemical elements bonded together. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds. So
column13: not an elementary substance. The chemical formula for argon contains one symbol: Ar. So
column14: argon is made of one chemical element. Substances that are made of one chemical element are elementary substances. So

column1: SOLUTION: The elementary substance among the choices is argon (Ar). This is because an elementary substance is a substance that is made up of only one type of atom. Argon (Ar) is an elementary substance because it is made up of only argon atoms. On the other hand
column2: cyclopropane (C3H6) and phosphine (PH3) are made up of more than one type of atom
column3: making them compounds
column4: not elementary substances."

column1: Which metal paper clip has a lower temperature?	['the metal paper clip with less thermal energy'

"Matter is made of tiny particles called atoms. Atoms are always moving.

column1: The energy of moving atoms is called thermal energy. The total amount of thermal energy in matter depends on three things: the type of matter
column2: the amount of matter
column3: and how fast the atoms are moving.

column1: Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter slow down
column2: the temperature goes down. The matter now has both less thermal energy and a lower temperature.

column1: What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70Â°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70Â°F. The two bricks have the same temperature
column2: but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So
column3: it has twice as much thermal energy."	The two metal paper clips are made of the same material and have the same mass. So
column4: the metal paper clip with less thermal energy has a lower temperature.	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The temperature of an object is directly related to its thermal energy. This means that if an object has more thermal energy
column2: it would also have a higher temperature. Similarly
column3: if a metal paper clip has less thermal energy
column4: its temperature would be lower. Since the two metal paper clips are identical except for their thermal energy
column5: the one with less thermal energy will have a lower temperature."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
a penny tarnishing
a piece of apple turning brown"	['Both are only physical changes.'
column2: 'Both are caused by heating.'
column3: 'Both are chemical changes.'
column4: 'Both are caused by cooling.']	2		closed choice	grade4	natural science	chemistry	Physical and chemical change	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Metal turning less shiny over time is called tarnishing. A penny tarnishing is a chemical change. When air touches the penny
column2: the surface of the penny changes into a different type of matter. This matter makes the penny dull.

column1: A piece of apple turning brown is a chemical change. The apple reacts with oxygen in the air and turns into a different type of matter.
If you scrape off the brown layer of the apple
column2: the inside is still white. The inside hasn't touched the air. So the chemical change didn't happen to that part of the apple.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: (2) Both are chemical changes.
SOLUTION: The penny tarnishing and the apple turning brown both involve a chemical reaction
column2: changing the original matter into a different type. This process is not caused by either heating or cooling
column3: and it's not a physical change because the original substances are altered at a molecular level. Therefore
column4: the answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: Based on this information

column1: Ace is a cow from this group. Ace has the heterozygous genotype Aa for the coat pattern gene."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"You need to determine Ace's phenotype for the coat pattern trait. First
column6: consider the alleles in Ace's genotype for the coat pattern gene. Then
column7: decide whether these alleles are dominant or recessive.

column1: The allele for white spots (a) is recessive to the allele for solid coloring (A). This means A is a dominant allele
column2: and a is a recessive allele.

column1: Ace's genotype of Aa has one dominant allele and one recessive allele. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Ace's phenotype for the coat pattern trait must be solid coloring."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Ace's genotype for the coat pattern gene is Aa
column2: meaning he carries one allele for solid coloring (A) and one for white spots (a). However
column3: the information suggests that the allele for solid coloring is dominant over the allele for white spots
column4: which is recessive. Therefore
column5: since Ace carries at least one dominant allele (A)
column6: his phenotype will show the trait for solid coloring

column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants

column3: which causes purple flowers

column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Boxer's genotype for the coat color gene is LL. Boxer's genotype of LL has only L allelles. The L allele is for a black coat. So

column3: and l is a recessive allele.

column1: Boxer's genotype of LL has two dominant alleles. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Boxer's phenotype for the coat color trait must be a black coat."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Boxer's genotype for the coat color gene is LL
column2: which means he has two dominant alleles for a black coat. Since the dominant trait overpowers the recessive trait
column3: Boxer will display the phenotype associated with the dominant allele. Therefore
column4: Boxer's phenotype for the coat color trait is a black coat."

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: Melting wax is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. The wax changes from solid to liquid. But it is still made of the same type of matter.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. They are not chemical changes.
Both are caused by heating.
Wax melting is caused by heating. But dust settling out of the air is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 3

SOLUTION: The answer choice ""Both are only physical changes"" is selected because both the changes mentioned - dust settling out of the air and melting wax - do not involve a transformation into a new substance. These changes can be reversed and the original substance can be obtained. Hence
column2: they are physical changes
column3: not chemical changes. Neither of the changes is caused by heating or cooling specifically
column4: hence option 3 is the correct answer."

column1: Which is a run-on sentence?	"[""He won't get lost

A run-on sentence is made up of two sentences that are joined without end punctuation or with just a comma.

column1: To fix a run-on sentence
column2: separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column4: 'false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist'
column5: 'ad hominem: an attack against the person making the argument
column6: rather than the argument itself']"	2		closed choice	grade10	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column7: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Candice's claim that the Loch Ness Monster isn't real is not valid because she's not Scottish. This is a personal attack on Candice's background that isn't relevant to whether her claim is valid. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 2
SOLUTION: The text discredits Candice's argument about the Loch Ness Monster not being real based on her nationality
column2: that she is not Scottish. This focuses on her personal trait
column3: rather than addressing the argument itself
column4: which is whether the Loch Ness Monster is real or not. This is an example of ad hominem
column5: a logical fallacy where the person making the argument is attacked instead of the argument itself. Therefore
column6: the answer is 2."

column1: This Punnett square shows a cross between two rats."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types	"Offspring phenotypes: dominant or recessive?

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with a dwarf body or a normal-sized body
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the body size trait. The question tells you that the B allele
column3: which is for a normal-sized body
column4: is dominant over the b allele
column5: which is for a dwarf body.

column1: A dwarf body is the recessive allele's version of the body size trait. A rat with the recessive version of the body size trait must have only recessive alleles for the body size gene. So
column2: offspring with a dwarf body must have the genotype bb.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype bb.
A normal-sized body is the dominant allele's version of the body size trait. A rat with the dominant version of the body size trait must have at least one dominant allele for the body size gene. So
column2: offspring with a normal-sized body must have the genotype BB or Bb.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype BB or Bb.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with a dwarf body to offspring with a normal-sized body is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring with a dwarf body. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring with a normal-sized body."	"ANSWER: 3

column1: SOLUTION: The Punnett square indicates the possible genetic combinations resulting from the cross of two individuals. Considering that the allele for a normal-sized body (B) is dominant over the allele for a dwarf body (b)
column2: it is observed that there are no bb combinations (which would result in a dwarf body) in the Punnett square. The genotypes BB or Bb (resulting in a normal-sized body) are present in all 4 boxes. Therefore
column3: the expected ratio of offspring with a dwarf body to offspring with a normal-sized body is 0:4. This is why option 3 is the correct answer."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column3: 'false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that if you're not a vegetarian, it must be because you despise animals. However, there may be a number of reasons why you eat meat. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a false dichotomy.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The statement ""If you're not a vegetarian
column2: then you must despise animals"" presents only two possible options when there are
column3: in fact
column4: many reasons someone might choose not to be a vegetarian. This is a classic example of a false dichotomy. There are multiple possibilities between being a vegetarian and despising animals
column5: such as dietary restrictions
column6: cultural practices
column8: the logical fallacy used in this statement is a false dichotomy."

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Nutmeg's genotype for the fur texture gene is ff. Nutmeg's genotype of ff has only f alleles. The f allele is for wavy fur. So
column6: Nutmeg's phenotype for the fur texture trait must be wavy fur.

column1: To check this answer
column2: consider whether Nutmeg's alleles are dominant or recessive. The allele for wavy fur (f) is recessive to the allele for straight fur (F). This means F is a dominant allele
column3: and f is a recessive allele.

column1: Nutmeg's genotype of ff has only recessive alleles. An organism with only recessive alleles for a gene will have the recessive allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Nutmeg's phenotype for the fur texture trait must be wavy fur."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The question asks about Nutmeg's phenotype
column2: which is an observable trait in an organism. From the information given
column3: Nutmeg has the homozygous genotype ff for the fur texture gene
column4: which is stated to be recessive and responsible for wavy fur. This means that Nutmeg will have wavy fur
column5: hence
column6: the correct answer is 0."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
acid rain weathering a marble statue
chemicals in a battery reacting to power a flashlight"	['Both are caused by cooling.'
column2: 'Both are chemical changes.'
column3: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column4: 'Both are caused by heating.']	1		closed choice	grade7	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Acid rain weathering a marble statue is a chemical change. The acid rain reacts with the outside of the statue and breaks it down into a different type of matter. This new matter is then washed away by the rain. Acid rain is a type of pollution. It forms when smoke from automobiles and factories mixes with water in clouds.

Acid rain is a type of pollution. It forms when automobiles and factories release smoke containing sulfur or nitrogen. Some of these chemicals react with water in the atmosphere. The reaction forms droplets of water that can fall back to the ground as acid rain.
Chemicals in a battery reacting to power a flashlight is a chemical change. When the flashlight is turned on
column2: the chemicals in the battery react with each other to form new chemicals. This creates electricity
column3: which powers the lightbulb.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Both the examples given - acid rain weathering a marble statue and chemicals in a battery reacting to power a flashlight - are instances of chemical changes. In both cases
column2: there is a reaction that results in new substances forming. This means that the original substances - the marble and the chemicals in the battery - have transformed into something new. Hence
column3: the correct answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Mr. Conway argues that we need to do more to prevent workplace injuries and fatalities. I doubt that someone so socially awkward would know a thing about office safety."	"['bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct'
column2: ""ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent""]"	1		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that being socially awkward determines knowledge of workplace safety. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to Mr. Conway's desire to prevent workplace injuries. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text uses an ad hominem fallacy
column2: attacking Mr. Conway's social awkwardness instead of addressing his argument about workplace safety. This is an attempt to undermine his credibility on the issue
column3: not based on the merit of his argument
column4: but on a personal characteristic. Therefore
column5: option 1 is the correct answer. This fallacy is a diversionary tactic meant to distract from the main argument by focusing on the individual's characteristics rather than their ideas or arguments."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column4: 'Both are caused by heating.']	1		closed choice	grade7	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Making paper from wood is a chemical change. Paper is made by mixing tiny pieces of wood with special chemicals. The wood reacts with the chemicals to form pulp. Wood and pulp are different types of matter.
Rust forming on a metal gate is a chemical change. As the gate rusts
column2: the metal turns into a different type of matter called rust. Rust is reddish-brown and falls apart easily.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Both 'making paper from wood' and 'rust forming on a metal gate' involve changes in the chemical composition of the substances. In both cases
column2: the original substances are transformed into new substances with different properties. So
column3: they are not merely physical changes
column4: nor are they caused by heating or cooling. Therefore
column5: the correct answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
a penny tarnishing

column4: 'Both are caused by cooling.']	2		closed choice	grade8	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Metal turning less shiny over time is called tarnishing. A penny tarnishing is a chemical change. When air touches the penny
column2: the surface of the penny changes into a different type of matter. This matter makes the penny dull.

column1: Firing a clay pot in a hot kiln is a chemical change. High temperatures cause the clay to slowly harden. After several hours in the kiln
column2: the clay will have changed into a different type of matter.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Firing clay is caused by heating. But a penny tarnishing is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 2
SOLUTION: Both a penny tarnishing and firing a clay pot in a hot kiln are examples of chemical changes. In both cases
column2: the initial substances are changed into new substances with different properties. Tarnishing of a penny is caused by reaction with oxygen in the air
column3: while firing a clay pot in a kiln causes the clay to harden and change its properties. Therefore
column4: the correct answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses verbal irony
column2: which involves saying one thing but implying something very different.

column1: As tidy as an overgrown garden shows verbal irony because an overgrown garden is not tidy."	"ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The figure of speech used in the text ""Jason's room is as tidy as an overgrown garden"" is verbal irony. This is because
column2: while the statement implies that Jason's room is tidy
column3: the comparison to an overgrown garden
column4: which is typically messy and unkempt
column5: suggests the opposite. Thus
column6: the statement is ironic because it says one thing but implies something very different."

column1: Which sentence uses a simile?	"[""Our boots were muddy pig's hooves.""

column1: A simile compares two things by saying that one is like the other. Similes often use the words like and as.

The sister's running and a cheetah's running are compared using the word like.
A cheetah is known for running fast
column2: so the simile means that the sister also runs fast.

column1: The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
The cat's fur and the night are compared using the word as.
The night is dark
column2: so the simile means that the cat's fur is also dark.

column1: A metaphor compares two things by saying that one of them is the other. Unlike similes
column2: metaphors don't use the word like or as.

column1: The snow formed a blanket over the town.
The snow and a blanket are compared without the word like or as.
A blanket is a large piece of cloth that completely covers a bed. The metaphor makes the reader imagine that the snow becomes a blanket
column2: covering the town completely.

column1: Using similes and metaphors in your writing can help you create an interesting picture for the reader."	"This sentence uses a simile:

The words boots and pig's hooves are compared using the word as.
This sentence uses a metaphor:

column3: ""Our boots were muddy pig's hooves"" is a metaphor

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=705x411 at 0x31266D790>	Which of these continents does the prime meridian intersect?	['South America'

column1: Lines of latitude show how far north or south a place is. We use units called degrees to describe how far a place is from the equator. The equator is the line located at 0Â° latitude. We start counting degrees from there.
Lines north of the equator are labeled N for north. Lines south of the equator are labeled S for south. Lines of latitude are also called parallels because each line is parallel to the equator.

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. The prime meridian is the line located at 0Â° longitude. Lines west of the prime meridian are labeled W. Lines east of the prime meridian are labeled E. Meridians meet at the north and south poles.
The equator goes all the way around the earth
column2: but the prime meridian is different. It only goes from the North Pole to the South Pole on one side of the earth. On the opposite side of the globe is another special meridian. It is labeled both 180Â°E and 180Â°W.

column1: Together
column2: lines of latitude and lines of longitude form a grid. You can use this grid to find the exact location of a place."	The prime meridian is the line at 0Â° longitude. It intersects Africa. It does not intersect Asia or South America.	"ANSWER: (2) Africa

column3: passes through the Royal Observatory in Greenwich
column4: London in the UK. It travels from the North Pole to the South Pole
column5: passing through Western Europe
column6: Western Africa
column8: the continent it intersects is Africa

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Did you know that Stanley is back home living with his parents again and won't get a job? Gosh
column2: millennials are such a lazy generation."	['ad hominem: an attack against the person making the argument
column3: rather than the argument itself'
column4: 'appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good'
column5: 'hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations']	2		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Stanley living with his parents means that millennials in general are lazy. However, one millennial's behavior does not necessarily reflect the behavior of the entire generation. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a hasty generalization.	ANSWER: 2
SOLUTION: The text is using the situation of one individual
column2: Stanley
column3: to make a sweeping statement about an entire generation
column4: namely millennials. This is a classic example of a hasty generalization
column5: where a broad claim is made based on too few observations. Therefore
column6: the logical fallacy used in the text is option 2

column1: A food web models how the matter eaten by organisms moves through an ecosystem. The arrows in a food web represent how matter moves between organisms in an ecosystem."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Ecological interactions	Interpret food webs I	"A food web is a model.

column2: the food web would be hard to understand. So
column3: each food web shows how some organisms in an ecosystem can get their food.

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

A food web has arrows that point from one organism to another. Each arrow shows the direction that matter moves when one organism eats another organism. An arrow starts from the organism that is eaten. The arrow points to the organism that is doing the eating.
An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.

An organism in a food web can also have more than one arrow pointing to it. This shows that the organism eats more than one other organism in the food web."	"Omnivores are consumers that eat both producers and other consumers. So
column2: an omnivore has arrows pointing to it from at least one producer and at least one consumer.

column1: The phytoplankton does not have any arrows pointing to it. So
column2: the phytoplankton is not an omnivore.

column1: The plainfin midshipman has an arrow pointing to it from the phytoplankton
column2: which is a producer. The plainfin midshipman also has an arrow pointing to it from the zooplankton
column3: which is a consumer. The plainfin midshipman eats a producer and a consumer
column4: so it is an omnivore.

column1: The kelp does not have any arrows pointing to it. So
column2: the kelp is not an omnivore.

column1: The kelp bass has an arrow pointing to it from the kelp
column2: which is a producer. The kelp bass also has arrows pointing to it from the zooplankton
column3: the plainfin midshipman
column4: and the black rockfish
column5: which are consumers. The kelp bass eats a producer and consumers
column6: so it is an omnivore.

column1: The sea urchin has only one arrow pointing to it. This arrow starts from the kelp
column2: which is a producer. So
column3: the sea urchin is a consumer but not an omnivore."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The plainfin midshipman is an omnivore because it eats both producers (phytoplankton) and consumers (zooplankton). This is evident from the arrows pointing towards it in the food web. The other organisms either only consume producers (like the sea urchin) or don't have any arrows pointing towards them (like kelp and phytoplankton)
column2: indicating they are not omnivores."

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description

bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself

Fallacy | Description

column1: Assonance is the repetition of a vowel sound in a series of nearby words.

column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So

column1: Some traits

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele

column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"The summer squash plant's genotype for the leaf texture gene is LL. The summer squash plant's genotype of LL has only L allelles. The L allele is for fuzzy leaves. So

column3: and l is a recessive allele.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Professor Harrell's research is untrustworthy because someone else at her university was caught falsifying data. However, this isn't necessarily true. The practices of one researcher at a university do not necessarily reflect the practices of another researcher at the same university. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text suggests that Professor Harrell's research may be unreliable because of the misconduct of another researcher from the same institution. It is trying to discredit Professor Harrell based on the negative actions of her colleague. This is an example of the ""guilt by association"" fallacy
column2: as it tries to tarnish Professor Harrell's credibility by associating her with undesired behavior without providing any direct evidence of her involvement in any malpractices."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=760x506 at 0x313328CE0>	Which of the following organisms is the primary consumer in this food web?	['gray fox'

column1: A food web models how the matter eaten by organisms moves through an ecosystem. The arrows in a food web represent how matter moves between organisms in an ecosystem."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Ecological interactions	Interpret food webs I	"A food web is a model.

A food web shows where organisms in an ecosystem get their food. Models can make things in nature easier to understand because models can represent complex things in a simpler way. If a food web showed every organism in an ecosystem
column2: the food web would be hard to understand. So
column3: each food web shows how some organisms in an ecosystem can get their food.

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

A food web has arrows that point from one organism to another. Each arrow shows the direction that matter moves when one organism eats another organism. An arrow starts from the organism that is eaten. The arrow points to the organism that is doing the eating.
An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.
An organism in a food web can also have more than one arrow pointing to it. This shows that the organism eats more than one other organism in the food web."	"Primary consumers eat producers. So
column2: in a food web
column3: primary consumers have arrows pointing to them from producers.

column1: The black bear has an arrow pointing to it from the persimmon tree. The persimmon tree is a producer
column2: so the black bear is a primary consumer.

column1: The beaver has an arrow pointing to it from the silver maple. The silver maple is a producer
column2: so the beaver is a primary consumer.

column1: The persimmon tree does not have any arrows pointing to it. So
column2: the persimmon tree is not a primary consumer.

column1: The silver maple does not have any arrows pointing to it. So
column2: the silver maple is not a primary consumer.

column1: The gray fox has arrows pointing to it from the swallowtail caterpillar and the pine vole. Neither the swallowtail caterpillar nor the pine vole is a producer

column1: Which sentence uses a simile?	"[""Mr. Dodson's long legs were sunflower stalks.""

column1: A simile compares two things by saying that one is like the other. Similes often use the words like and as.

A cheetah is known for running fast
column2: so the simile means that the sister also runs fast.

column1: The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
The cat's fur and the night are compared using the word as.
The night is dark
column2: so the simile means that the cat's fur is also dark.

column1: A metaphor compares two things by saying that one of them is the other. Unlike similes
column2: metaphors don't use the word like or as.

column1: The snow formed a blanket over the town.
The snow and a blanket are compared without the word like or as.

Mr. Dodson's legs were as long as sunflower stalks.

This sentence uses a metaphor:

The words legs and sunflower stalks are compared without the word like or as."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
