When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that free gym memberships will result in lower productivity. However, offering free gym memberships doesn't necessarily suggest that employees will spend all their time at the gym rather than at work. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text is a clear example of a straw man fallacy. The human resource department's position is misrepresented
column2: suggesting that they want employees to spend all their time at the gym and not work. In reality
column3: the department is simply advocating for free gym memberships
column4: not implying that work should be neglected. Therefore
column5: the argument is built on a distorted view of the original proposition."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=243x239 at 0x3126461E0>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to offspring with green body feathers? Choose the most likely ratio.	['4:0'
column5: '1:3']	1	"In a group of budgerigar parakeets
column6: some individuals have green body feathers and others have blue body feathers. In this group
column7: the gene for the body feather color trait has two alleles. The allele for green body feathers (B) is dominant over the allele for blue body feathers (b).

column1: This Punnett square shows a cross between two budgerigar parakeets."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types	"Offspring phenotypes: dominant or recessive?

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with blue body feathers or green body feathers
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the body feather color trait. The question tells you that the B allele
column3: which is for green body feathers
column4: is dominant over the b allele
column5: which is for blue body feathers.

column1: Blue body feathers is the recessive allele's version of the body feather color trait. A budgerigar parakeet with the recessive version of the body feather color trait must have only recessive alleles for the body feather color gene. So
column2: offspring with blue body feathers must have the genotype bb.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype bb.

Green body feathers is the dominant allele's version of the body feather color trait. A budgerigar parakeet with the dominant version of the body feather color trait must have at least one dominant allele for the body feather color gene. So
column2: offspring with green body feathers must have the genotype BB or Bb.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype BB or Bb.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to offspring with green body feathers is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring with blue body feathers. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring with green body feathers."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The Punnett square showed that all 4 boxes had the genotype of BB or Bb
column2: which corresponds to green body feathers. Since the green body feather allele is dominant
column3: there are no possibilities for offspring to have blue body feathers. Therefore
column4: the expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to offspring with green body feathers is 0:4
column5: corresponding to choice 1."

column1: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?	"[""Several competent city council members have been elected in Seaside

column5: make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.

column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: 2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they
column2: them
column3: their
column4: theirs
column5: it
column6: or its is used without its antecedent.

column1: They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.

column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.

The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes."	"The first answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun them could refer to the citizens or several competent city council members.

column2: but the mayor's office has prevented them from significantly influencing policy.

column1: The second answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. The text has been rewritten so that the meaning is clear.

column2: but the mayor's office has prevented the council members from significantly influencing policy."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The first answer choice contains a vague prononym reference. The pronoun 'them' could refer to either 'the citizens of Seaside' or 'several competent city council members'

column4: removing any ambiguity."

column3: and more are discovered all the time. There are several theories about why there are so many different beetles
column4: but fossils give us one clue. Using fossils
column5: scientists can see how many ancient species used to exist but are now extinct. They found that beetles have the lowest extinction rates of any animal ever. This means that beetle species don't die out as often as other animals. Beetles seem to have an edge over other creatures.

column1: One of the reasons beetles thrive is their body design. Most beetle species have two pairs of wings. The front pair is hard and thick like a helmet. These wings protect the rear set of wings and the beetle's abdomen. The front wings are not used for flying. Instead
column2: the wings shield the beetle's veins and other soft parts from harm.

column1: Beetle species live all over the world and have many different types of food available to them. Most beetles are omnivores. That means they eat both plants and animals. Their flexible diets help them adapt to different habitats
column2: even when a certain food source becomes scarce. Beetles can find something to eat
column3: no matter what.

column1: Finally
column2: beetles can move quickly over long distances. If there are any harmful changes to their environment
column3: they can usually find a better place to live. For example
column4: many animal species have died out during ice ages
column5: when Earth's temperature has dropped for a long time. But many beetles survived this dangerous time. Beetles quickly notice temperature changes in their environment. So
column6: they can quickly respond by migrating to a warmer place. No wonder there are so many beetles in the world. They have what it takes to stay alive."	closed choice	grade5	language science	reading-comprehension	Informational texts: level 1	Read passages about animals	Informational texts include many facts
column8: and details. Authors don't always directly state how these things connect to each other. So
column9: you may need to make guesses
column11: to understand how the ideas from the text fit together. Inferences can help you understand the whole text and draw conclusions about the information. Be sure to base your inferences on details found in the text as well as things you already know.	"Think about these details from the text:

column1: Fossils can show how many ancient species have gone extinct.
Fossil evidence shows that beetles die out less often than any other animal.
Beetles' low extinction rate helps explain the large number of beetle species.
In order to show that beetles die out less often than other animals
column2: scientists must have compared different animals' extinction rates. To do this
column3: they would need to figure out how many ancient species have gone extinct.

column1: Based on these clues
column2: you can guess that fossil evidence let scientists compare the number of extinct beetles to the number of other extinct animals. This helped them figure out that beetles die out less often than other animals
column3: which explains the huge number of beetle species."	"ANSWER: 3

column1: SOLUTION: The text provides several insights into how fossils have helped scientists understand why there are so many species of beetles. It specifically mentions that fossils have shown that beetles have the lowest extinction rates of any animal
column2: suggesting that they don't die out as often as other species. This means that scientists have used fossils to compare the number of extinct beetles with the number of other extinct animals
column3: thus understanding the large number of beetle species. Therefore
column4: option 3 is the correct choice based on the information provided in the text."

I knocked on the door it opened.

column2: we ran inside.

column1: To fix a run-on sentence
column2: separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence
column3: and capitalize the second sentence.

These clauses are joined without a coordinating conjunction or punctuation

column1: A food web models how the matter eaten by organisms moves through an ecosystem. The arrows in a food web represent how matter moves between organisms in an ecosystem."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Ecological interactions	Interpret food webs I	"A food web is a model.

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

A food web has arrows that point from one organism to another. Each arrow shows the direction that matter moves when one organism eats another organism. An arrow starts from the organism that is eaten. The arrow points to the organism that is doing the eating.
An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.

An organism in a food web can also have more than one arrow pointing to it. This shows that the organism eats more than one other organism in the food web."	"Tertiary consumers eat secondary consumers. So
column2: in a food web

column1: The beaver has an arrow pointing to it from the silver maple. The silver maple is not a secondary consumer
column2: so the beaver is not a tertiary consumer.

column1: The gray fox has an arrow pointing to it from the pine vole. The pine vole is a secondary consumer
column2: so the gray fox is a tertiary consumer.

column1: The black racer has an arrow pointing to it from the pine vole. The pine vole is a secondary consumer

column1: The black bear has arrows pointing to it from the persimmon tree

column3: and the beaver. None of these organisms is a secondary consumer

column1: The silver maple does not have any arrows pointing to it. So

column3: which is a secondary consumer. As per the given definitions
column4: a tertiary consumer is an organism that consumes secondary consumers
column5: which in this case
column6: the black racer satisfies by feeding on the pine vole. Therefore
column7: the black racer is the tertiary consumer."

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.

A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.

A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Neil
column2: you didn't vote in the last election

When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Neil must not care about democracy, because he didn't vote in the election. However, there may be a number of reasons why Neil didn't vote in the election. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a false dichotomy.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The text is using a false dichotomy to suggest that Neil's lack of participation in the election is equivalent to him not caring about democracy. This argument overlooks the possible reasons for Neil's non-voting
column2: such as health issues
column3: travel
column4: ignorance about the voting process
column5: etc. Hence
column6: the text presents an argument with only two choices when there could be more

column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Milk going sour is a chemical change. The type of matter in the milk slowly changes. The new matter that is formed gives the milk its sour taste.
Deep-frying chicken is a chemical change. The heat causes the matter in the chicken to change. Cooked chicken and raw chicken are different types of matter.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Cooking is caused by heating. But milk going sour is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: (3)
SOLUTION: Both milk going sour and deep-frying chicken represent chemical changes. In the case of milk going sour
column2: a chemical change occurs as bacteria in the milk convert lactose into lactic acid. With deep-frying chicken
column3: the heat causes a chemical reaction that changes the composition of the chicken. Therefore
column4: the commonality between these two changes is that they are both chemical changes
column5: not physical changes
column6: and they are not solely caused by heating or cooling."

An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Ronald
column2: you drive a beat-up car from the 1980s. For this reason
column3: we can never allow you to be a lifeguard at the community pool."	"['false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist'
column4: ""ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent""]"	1		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that people who drive old cars are likely to be poor lifeguards. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to someone's qualifications to be a lifeguard. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text implies that Ronald's ability to perform the duties of a lifeguard is directly related to the condition and age of his car
column2: which is a personal and irrelevant aspect. This is a classic example of an ad hominem fallacy
column3: where an argument is directed against a person rather than the position they are maintaining. Therefore
column4: the logical fallacy used in the text is ad hominem."

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.

A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.

column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after

column1: The sperm fuse with eggs in the female part. This is called fertilization. Self-fertilization happens when a sperm from a moss plant fertilizes an egg from the same plant. Cross-fertilization happens when a sperm from one moss plant fertilizes an egg from a different moss plant.

column4: which are produced by the moss in a different phase of its life cycle

column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color geneâ€”one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Tiki's genotype for the body feather color gene is bb. Tiki's genotype of bb has only b alleles. The b allele is for blue body feathers. So
column6: Tiki's phenotype for the body feather color trait must be blue body feathers.

column1: To check this answer
column2: consider whether Tiki's alleles are dominant or recessive. The allele for blue body feathers (b) is recessive to the allele for green body feathers (B). This means B is a dominant allele
column3: and b is a recessive allele.

column1: Tiki's genotype of bb has only recessive alleles. An organism with only recessive alleles for a gene will have the recessive allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Tiki's phenotype for the body feather color trait must be blue body feathers."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Tiki's genotype for the body feather color gene is bb. Each b allele is for blue body feathers
column2: and Tiki has two of these b alleles. The b alleles are recessive
column3: but since Tiki has two of them
column4: there is no dominant allele present to override the recessive trait. This means Tiki's phenotype will reflect the recessive trait
column5: which is blue body feathers."

column1: Select the part whose main job is to use energy from sunlight to make sugar in a plant cell.	['chromosomes'

column4: 'vacuole']	1		closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Cells	Identify functions of plant cell parts	"Plant cells are made up of many different parts. Each cell part has a function that helps the cell survive and grow.

column1: Some cell parts are called organelles. Organelles are cell structures that are surrounded by their own membranes. Here are some of the organelles in plant cells:

Chloroplasts and mitochondria work together to help the cell get the energy it needs. The chloroplasts use photosynthesis to make sugar. The mitochondria break down this sugar and release energy that the cell can use for all of its activities.

The nucleus directs cell activities by sending instructions to different parts of the cell. The nucleus contains structures called chromosomes. The chromosomes are made mostly of hereditary material called DNA. DNA contains information that the cell uses for growth and activities. These instructions tell ribosomes how to build molecules called proteins
column2: which make up cell structures and help chemical reactions happen in the cell.

column1: The endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle that helps ribosomes build proteins. The nucleus sends instructions for making proteins to ribosomes. Ribosomes can attach to the endoplamic reticulum. The endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes use these instructions to make proteins that the cell needs to survive and grow.
After proteins are made in the endoplasmic reticulum
column2: they can be transferred to the Golgi. The Golgi is an organelle made up of flat
column3: stacked membranes. The Golgi sorts and packages proteins and other substances. Then
column4: the Golgi sends these substances to different parts of the cell. Some of these substances are sent to the cell membrane and released from the cell.

column1: In plant cells
column2: the vacuole stores waste
column3: water
column4: and nutrients such as sugar. Most plant cells have one vacuole.

column1: Other cell parts are not surrounded by their own membranes. These cell parts are not organelles.
The cell wall is the cell's tough outer covering. It gives the cell strength and stiffness and helps the cell keep its shape.
On the inside of the cell wall is a thin layer called the cell membrane. This layer is a membrane
column2: but it does not have a membrane surrounding it
column3: so it is not an organelle. The cell membrane controls which substances enter and leave the cell.

column1: The cytoplasm is a thick liquid that fills the space inside the cell. The cytoplasm also helps the cell keep its shape and supports the other cell parts."	"Chloroplasts use photosynthesis to make sugar. First

SOLUTION: I chose answer number 1 because chloroplasts are the part of a plant cell responsible for photosynthesis. They are the organelles that capture sunlight and use it to convert water and carbon dioxide into glucose

column3: and it wouldn't be possible without chloroplasts."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=760x506 at 0x3125DF350>	Which of the following organisms is the secondary consumer in this food web?	['persimmon tree'

column2: the food web would be hard to understand. So

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.
An organism in a food web can also have more than one arrow pointing to it. This shows that the organism eats more than one other organism in the food web."	"Secondary consumers eat primary consumers

column1: The beaver has an arrow pointing to it from the silver maple. The silver maple is not a primary consumer
column2: so the beaver is not a secondary consumer.

column1: The persimmon tree does not have any arrows pointing to it. So
column2: the persimmon tree is not a secondary consumer.

column1: The black bear has arrows pointing to it from the swallowtail caterpillar and the beaver. The swallowtail caterpillar and the beaver are primary consumers

column4: the black bear is the secondary consumer."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that being socially awkward determines knowledge of workplace safety. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to Mr. Carlson's desire to prevent workplace injuries. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text attacks Mr. Carlson's social awkwardness instead of addressing his argument about improving workplace safety. This is a classic example of an ad hominem fallacy
column2: where the person's character is attacked rather than their argument. It attempts to discredit Mr. Carlson's argument by criticizing his social skills
column3: which are irrelevant to the topic of workplace safety. Therefore
column4: the correct answer is 0 - ad hominem."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Senator Pena announced today that she plans to cut funding to early childhood education programs. The last thing we need is a government official who hates children!"	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']"	0		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Senator Pena hates children, because she wants to cut education funding. However, the fact that Senator Pena wants to cut education funding doesn't necessarily suggest that she hates children. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text misrepresents Senator Pena's position of cutting funding to early childhood education programs as a sign of her hating children. It exaggerates her stance to make it easier to argue against
column2: which is the definition of a straw man fallacy. This does not necessarily mean she hates children but is a strategy to discredit her intentions. Therefore
column3: the logical fallacy used in the text is a straw man."

An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.

A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.

A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column4: 'slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences']	1		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Hazel cannot be insightful about foreign affairs because she grew up on a farm. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to whether she knows about foreign affairs. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The text is using an ad hominem fallacy to discredit Hazel's potential insights about foreign affairs by pointing out that she grew up on a farm. column2: she couldn't possibly understand or have insightful thoughts about foreign affairs

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So

column1: Some traits

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers

column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"You need to determine Zelda's phenotype for the horns trait. First

column2: Zelda's phenotype for the horns trait must be not having horns."	"ANSWER: 1

column4: the dominant gene for not having horns will determine her phenotype. Thus

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Don't try to tell me that you only watch educational programming
column2: Marie! I know for a fact that your sister only watches reality television."	['hasty generalization: a very broad claim based on very little evidence'
column3: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']	1		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Marie must watch reality television, because her sister watches reality television. However, even though Marie's sister watches reality television, that doesn't necessarily mean that Marie does, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text assumes that Marie watches reality television just because her sister does. This is an example of guilt by association
column2: where the actions or characteristics of one person are applied to another simply because they are related or connected in some way. The argument doesn't provide any direct evidence about Marie's viewing habits
column3: but rather tries to discredit her claim by associating her with her sister's habits."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column3: pure
column4: and unchanged. It's better for us."	['bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct'
column5: 'appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good'
column6: 'circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself']	1		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column7: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that raw milk is better than pasteurized milk because pasteurization isn't a natural process. However, raw milk isn't necessarily healthier for humans just because it's unprocessed. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as an appeal to nature.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text argues that because pasteurization is a human-made process
column2: it is not as good as drinking raw
column3: unprocessed milk. This is an example of an appeal to nature fallacy
column4: where the assumption is made that anything natural is inherently better or healthier. It ignores the fact that pasteurization was implemented to remove harmful bacteria
column5: and raw milk is not necessarily healthier for humans. Therefore
column6: the logical fallacy used in the text is appeal to nature."

column1: In a physical change

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a chemical change

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: A copper statue turning green is a chemical change. The copper reacts with oxygen in the air. This reaction forms a different type of matter called copper oxide. The copper oxide is green.

If you scrape off the brown part of the avocado
column2: the inside will still be green. The inside hasn't touched the air. So the chemical change hasn't happened to that part of the avocado.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: Both a copper statue turning green and a piece of avocado turning brown are examples of chemical changes. In these instances
column2: the substances react with oxygen in the air to form a different type of matter - copper oxide in the case of the statue
column3: and a brown compound in the case of the avocado. Neither change is caused by heating or cooling
column4: and they are not mere physical changes

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column2: the F allele

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
a puddle freezing into ice on a cold night
cutting an orange"	['Both are caused by heating.'
column2: 'Both are caused by cooling.'
column3: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column4: 'Both are chemical changes.']	2		closed choice	grade3	natural science	chemistry	Physical and chemical change	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it reÂ­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: A puddle freezing into ice on a cold night is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. Liquid water freezes and becomes solid
column3: but it is still made of water. A different type of matter is not formed.

column1: Cutting an orange is a physical change. The orange gets a different shape. But it is still made of the same type of matter as the uncut orange.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. They are not chemical changes.
Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.
Both are caused by cooling.
A puddle freezing is caused by cooling. But cutting an orange is not."	"ANSWER: (2)

SOLUTION: Both a puddle freezing into ice on a cold night and cutting an orange are physical changes. Physical changes involve alterations to the physical properties of a substance without any change to its molecular composition. In these instances
column2: the water in the puddle and the orange retain their original properties
column3: just their forms change
column4: hence the answer is (2) Both are only physical changes."

column1: "Which type of sentence is this?
Wendy is a competitive horseback rider
column2: and she will be competing in the next World Equestrian Games
column3: which are held every four years."	['simple'
column4: 'compound'
column5: 'complex'
column6: 'compound-complex']	3		closed choice	grade10	language science	grammar	Phrases and clauses	Is the sentence simple
column9: or compound-complex?	"A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a predicate.

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw the flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column11: and while. Relative pronouns include that

column1: If she ever gets the chance
column2: Terri would love to visit the Egyptian pyramids.

column1: During his trip to Italy
column2: Tony visited the Trevi Fountain
column3: which is in Rome.

column1: A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.
After Samantha left work
column2: she stopped at the bank
column3: and then she went to the gym.

column1: Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.

Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins."	"The sentence is compound-complex. It is made up of two independent clauses and a dependent clause. The dependent clause begins with the relative pronoun which.
Wendy is a competitive horseback rider
column2: and she will be competing in the next World Equestrian Games
column3: which are held every four years."	"ANSWER: 3

column1: SOLUTION: The sentence given is a compound-complex sentence. This is because it is composed of two independent clauses: ""Wendy is a competitive horseback rider"" and ""she will be competing in the next World Equestrian Games""
column2: which can stand alone as sentences. Additionally
column3: it contains a dependent clause
column4: ""which are held every four years
column5: that cannot stand alone as a complete thought. Thus
column6: the sentence combines the features of both compound and complex sentences

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?
Polly's phone slipped out of her pocket
column2: landing in the toilet with a plop."	['idiom'
column3: 'onomatopoeia']	1		closed choice	grade10	language science	figurative-language	Literary devices	Classify figures of speech: review	"Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses onomatopoeia
column2: a word that expresses a sound.

column1: Plop represents the sound of the phone landing in the toilet."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text uses onomatopoeia
column2: a figure of speech where words are used to mimic the sounds they represent. In this case
column3: the word 'plop' is an auditory representation of the sound made when Polly's phone lands in the toilet. Therefore
column4: the correct answer is option 1
column5: onomatopoeia
column6: and not option 0
column8: which is a phrase expressing a sentiment not deducible from the individual words."
